choices.D: Install to a secondary internal HDD

questions.question_text: While attempting to install a new program, an end user is notified the workstation meets the memory requirements, but it does not meet the requirements for free space. Due to time constraints, the user needs a quick way to install and access the program. Which of the following is the user's BEST option given the situation?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The only reason I pick "A" is because it is the only option that can be performed without getting up from a chair.

All the other options involved leaving the place and go back to provide the hardware and install it.

So 
C is excluded as install it on a optical drive is not really doable. Should make an installation ad create an ISO to buon on the optical drive

D is good as far as there's a secondari hard drive, otherwise would need to go and get one and then fit it in order to install the software

B Is better than c as is quick fit through UPNP, but still have to go in store to provide it.

A If we consider the terminal is surely connected to the network, can just decide to install the software on the network drive giving an immediate solution.

The trick is the rush to have the software, so I chose the quickest option
A,B,Cand D are all options listed as available. Therefore D is the best answer.

comments.content: I think the USB drive here is referring to thumb drive.

discussion.content: I don't understand why this isn't B. You can plug an external HDD via USB.
why is network drive better than internal HDD ? is it because we are assuming the secondary HDD is not installed so installing it takes longer ?

comments.content: Correct. This is all assuming as well that a network drive already exists. But it's faster to change the install directory than to physically shut down the PC, (having an HDD on hand), installing it, and then booting the PC back up.

discussion.content:
As he is trying to remedy the vulnerability, he already analyzed the risk.
User acceptance isn't needed in this scenario - they don't need any training, and the change doesn't affect their work.
A backout plan is a MUST. You mustn't apply any change without a blackout plan/rolling plan.
Therefore the answer is C and D.

It says tech has already identified significant issues and is performing remediation, so I think risk analysis is not the key thing here. He needs to create a plan to implement change and to back out if the plan fails.
From the objectives: plan for change, end user acceptance and change board (approvals) The question ask what to submit before the approvals. am i making sense?
He wanted "applying updates to end usersג€™ computers" Guys he need to carry out risk analyses and create backup plan, that's how I'm thinking.

To me, this question sounds like techs will need to complete these 2 forms before making updates. So these are forms/templates to be used in the change process. Looking at it this was I can agree with Planning and Backout forms being most important. Option A would be 3rd on the list, for major updates, I assume.
This question needs to be a bit more specific. all of those processes could be documented.
Does anyone have a clue as to what the question is about? Is it Change Management?

comments.content: Precisely. Professor Messer details it in a video of the same name (Change Management)

questions.question_text: A security administrator does some network testing and identifies significant issues with security on desktop computers. As part of remediation, the network administrator is developing documentation based on best practices for applying updates to end users' computers. The network administrator must create the process documentation needed to submit back to the security administrator for approval. Which of the following process documents would the network administrator MOST likely create? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: micromanagement

comments.content: I would assume other coleague has duty assigned by supervisor as well.
It's his supervisor's job to manage the team workload, re-assign as needed, and overall scheduling to ensure customer expectations are met. That's exactly his job unless this is a two person company.

discussion.content:
Why a coleague would not assist him..
I guess supervisor is not his secretary to reschedule appointments?

choices.B: Move the appointments to the next business day.
choices.D: Continue to work on the current call, and get to the other as soon as possible.
choices.A: Contact his supervisor so the supervisor can make scheduling changes.
choices.C: Reach out to a colleague to assist in completing the jobs.

questions.question_text: Joe, a technician, has his daily plans forwarded to him by his supervisor. Upon arrival to the second support call of the day, Joe realizes the issue will require much more time than initially scheduled, and several support calls will not be completed. Which of the following would be the appropriate action for Joe?

A user's computer is running slow even when only one program is open. A technician discovers the CPU is running at 100%, and there is a significant amount of outgoing network traffic.
Which of the following is MOST likely causing the high resource usage?

discussion.content: botnet   Network of computers infected with malware that can be controlled to do the bidding of the malware developers, or anyone who pays them. A common use is carrying out distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks.

Selected Answer: B
The keyphrase "Significant Network activity" Your PC is being used without your consent, points to it being a bot

choices.C: The computer is receiving a DDoS attack
choices.B: The computer is part of a botnet
choices.D: A software firewall is blocking traffic

questions.question_text:
Joe, a technician, receives notification that a share for production data files on the network is encrypted. Joe suspects a crypto virus is active. He checks the rights of the network share to see which departments have access. He then searches the user directories of those departmental users who are looking for encrypted files. He narrows his search to a single user's computer.
Once the suspected source of the virus is discovered and removed from the network, which of the following should Joe do NEXT?

discussion.content: Based on what I expect from this site, I would have expected "take the infected PC on a date, get it drunk and convince it to behave from now on" to not only BE an option, but selected AS THE CORRECT ANSWER

comments.content:
"Once the suspected source of the virus is discovered and 'removed' from the network"
Isn't that D is the correct answer from the above sentence.

discussion.content:
[The “source (computer) of the virus was removed from the network” (quarantined) – what’s next?]
B. Scan and remove the malware from the infected system. [The actual next step, “Disable System Restore” is missing from the answers, but the next step after that is “Remediate” (remove the infection).
The 7 Steps of Malware Removal (IQDRSEE): {remember with: Eye Q Doctor See}
1 - Identify and research malware symptoms
2 - Quarantine infected systems (isolate it)
3 - Disable System Restore (to prevent any new restore points)
4 - Remediate infected systems (update antimalware software/scan and use removal techniques)
5 - Schedule scans and run updates
6 - Enable system restore and create restore point
7 - Educate the user

Selected Answer: B
This question is about whether you know the steps to remove malware in the 1002 objectives. So it says the system has been removed from the network aka quarantined (step 2 Quarantine). There's no objection to disable system restore (step 3) so I guess it's not a windows system, the next step is to update the antivirus software, but that's not included so maybe that's done automatically or it's a zero-day and you're using a tool to remove it, whatever, the only next option left remaining is scan and remove. The other options are clearly next after removing.

The computer was removed from the NETWORK. Not the virus getting removed from the system. So once the computer has been Quarantined aka removed from the network to prevent the malware spreading, then we choose B which is about removing the malware off the infected system,

When the inevitable happens and either your computer or one of your user’s
computers gets infected by malware such as a computer virus, you need to
follow certain steps to stop the problem from spreading and get the computer
back up safely into service. The 1002 exam outlines the following multistep
process as the best practice procedures for malware removal:
1. Identify and research malware symptoms.
2. Quarantine the infected systems.
3. Disable System Restore (in Windows).
4. Remediate the infected systems.
A. Update the anti-malware software.
B. Scan and use removal techniques (Safe Mode, Preinstallation
Environment).
5. Schedule scans and run updates.
6. Enable System Restore and create a restore point (in Windows).
7. Educate the end user.

comments.content: A is educate the user. The answer you are talking about is B.

discussion.content: A is the answer. They said the suspected source of the virus is discovered and removed from the network. After removing the affected pc, the next step is Scan and remove the malware from the infected system.

why scan and remove when he has already "Once the suspected source of the virus is discovered and removed from the network" The virus have been removed we are told why you ask then to remove . It need to be D.

comments.content: No, the "source of the virus" is a computer on the network. So, the computer is then removed from the network. Next step would be to scan, etc. (i.e. B).
"Once the suspect source is discovered and removed from the network" probably means that the infected computer is identified and isolate.

discussion.content:
"Once the suspected source of the virus is discovered and removed from the network"
its means "Quarantine infected systems (isolate it) " so , the next step is "Schedule scans and run updates" (Answer is B)

B is correct but the wording of the question is so tricky that it's easy to get it wrong. I answered differently at first but after reading the question several times I can agree with B. I hope this question is reworded for the actual exam.
another trick question... they didn't use the word quarantine. why do they put these tricky worded questions to catch you out. it's annoying.
Yes, that was tricky, he already removed from the network but not the computer system itself.

comments.content: The "source" of the virus was removed. I believe this means the computer was removed from the network, meaning B is correct.

discussion.content:
Scanning the device and removing the malware from it is the most correct answer. Had to think about this one for a bit. While the technician has isolated the device and supposed virus source, he has not explicitly run a scan of the device. Scanning will confirm if the suspected source was correct, and properly clean the device.
Scheduling scans and performing Windows updates is incorrect; a scan should be conducted first before Windows updates and immediately, not on a timed schedule.
Creating a restore point is incorrect; no scan has been explicitly performed. The malware may have persisted up to this point.
End user education is incorrect; the technician has not yet completed implementing his solution.

choices.A: Educate the end user on safe browsing and email habits.
choices.B: Scan and remove the malware from the infected system.
choices.C: Create a system restore point and reboot the system.
choices.D: Schedule antivirus scans and perform Windows updates.
